weeklyTopNews.title: PM pledges $131.4b towards Australia's public hospitals in wake of COVID-19
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Federal Government will pour $131.4 billion into Australia's public hospitals to future-proof the health system against crises like COVID-19. Announcing the huge cash injection in a national address this afternoon, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the money will be used to improve health outcomes for all Australians. The government will start proceedings with an additional $34.4 billion in funding to hospitals from July 1 this year.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions eased in WA with almost all businesses set to reopen under new rules
weeklyTopNews.summary: West Australians can gather in groups of up to 100 people from June 6 as the state moves to phase three of relaxing coronavirus restrictions, with the "vast majority" of businesses affected by the lockdown permitted to reopen. Up to 300 people will be permitted in some settings, like for indoor and outdoor venues, with multiple divided spaces with up to 100 people in each space. The Premier said Western Australia would be the first state to move away from the one person per four square metres rule under phase three, replacing it with a one person per two square metres rule.

weeklyTopNews.title: Scrapping jobkeeper too early risks Australian economy falling off a cliff, Covid inquiry told
weeklyTopNews.summary: The governor of the Reserve Bank has warned the government the jobkeeper program may need to be kept going beyond its current cut-off date to avoid the Australian economy falling off a cliff. Statements made by the RBA governor, Philip Lowe, and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority chairman, Wayne Byres, about the risk of economic collapse when the jobkeeper program expires at the end of September will increase pressure on the Morrison government to defy a ginger group of Coalition backbenchers and extend stimulus into the new year.

weeklyTopNews.title: Tourism taskforce pushing ahead with 'ambitious' plan to kickstart air travel to New Zealand, Pacific
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australians will be allowed to travel to NZ and the Pacific from July if an 'ambitious' timetable produced by the Tourism Restart Taskforce goes ahead. The taskforce meets once a week to discuss a plan to reopen the tourism industry, with government representatives often in attendance. The taskforce recently approved a timetable covering domestic travel and events, and possible international travel resumption dates. Travel between Australia and New Zealand and the Pacific would restart by July 1 , while September 10 was earmarked for potential travel to countries deemed "safe". All international travel could be resumed by 2021 if the plan is approved.

weeklyTopNews.title: Queensland man, 30, becomes youngest person to die from coronavirus in Australia
weeklyTopNews.summary: A 30-year-old Queensland man has died from coronavirus, making him Australia's youngest COVID-19 victim to date. The man's partner is currently being isolated at Rockhampton Hospital and is also showing COVID-19 symptoms. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said the man was from Blackwater in central Queensland and urged anyone in the area with flu-like symptoms to get tested urgently.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW Government freezes staff salaries to save $3 billion amid coronavirus pandemic
weeklyTopNews.summary: The NSW Government will freeze pay rises for public sector workers for 12 months, as it deals with rising unemployment across the state due to the coronavirus pandemic. Under the current wages policy, hundreds of thousands of public sector employees can pursue a 2.5 per cent pay rise each year. However, under the wage freeze policy, salaries will remain unchanged for 12 months. Premier Gladys Berejiklian said the measure will save about $3 billion and has assured government workers there will be no job losses.

weeklyTopNews.title: Scott Morrison outlines 'JobMaker' plan for post-coronavirus economic recovery
weeklyTopNews.summary: The prime minister on Tuesday unveiled part of the coalition's economic plan designed to claw the nation back from pandemic-induced pain.  Under Mr Morrison's plan, funding would be more closely linked to skill gaps based on what businesses need. Industry will be given greater power to shape training, with pilot schemes across human services, digital technologies and mining used as examples for other sectors. Mr Morrison made the case to ditch a "clunky and unresponsive" system in favour of more consistency across states and greater transparency around spending. Mr Morrison will flag changes to the funding model which sees $1.5 billion of federal cash flow to state governments annually for skills and training.

weeklyTopNews.title: Human trials of potential coronavirus vaccine begin in Melbourne
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australia's first human trials of a potential COVID-19 vaccine have begun in Melbourne, with about 130 people involved in the program. Clinical research organisation Nucleus Network will be in charge of the early stages of testing the vaccine NVX-CoV2373, before the trial expands to Brisbane within a week. If it is successful, researchers hope 100 million doses of the vaccine can be made by the end of the year and 1.5 billion next year. Preliminary results for phase one are expected in July, and phase two results by the end of the year.

weeklyTopNews.title: South Australia records first new coronavirus case in 19 days amid easing restrictions
weeklyTopNews.summary: South Australia has recorded its first COVID-19 case in 19 days — an overseas traveller who was given an exemption from quarantine. SA Health said the woman aged in her 50s had travelled from overseas to Victoria where she had been quarantined in a hotel for less than a week, before travelling to South Australia. She was given an exemption to fly to South Australia for "compelling family reasons" and was tested on arrival at Adelaide Airport. The new case comes amid an accelerated easing of coronavirus restrictions in South Australia. It is the first new case since that of a man in his 70s was declared on May 7, and follows a declaration of no remaining active cases which occurred just over a week later.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus restrictions to be relaxed in South Australia ahead of schedule
weeklyTopNews.summary: Stage two restrictions were originally due to ease on June 8, but that was previously brought forward to June 5 and now to Monday, June 1. Cinemas, theatres, galleries, museums, beauty salons, gyms and indoor fitness centres across South Australia will be able to open from next Monday, with the SA Government bringing forward the relaxation of coronavirus restrictions. Those venues, along with pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes, will be able to admit up to 80 patrons, provided they can contain them to groups of 20 in discrete rooms or areas within the business. Furthermore, up to 50 mourners will be allowed at funerals, non-contact outdoor sport will be able to resume on June 1 and competition for outdoor contact sports can resume from June 25.

weeklyTopNews.title: Schools are reopening, so here's a guide to the situation in each state and territory
weeklyTopNews.summary: Government advice on whether students should attend schools amid the ongoing coronavirus situation varies widely across Australia, and has sometimes led to confusion and controversy. Some states still have restrictions on school attendance while some states have never had restrictions on school attendance; however Prime Minister Scott Morrison wants all public schools to return to face-to-face learning by June. Here's the latest on when schools will reopen in your state or territory, if they haven't already.

weeklyTopNews.title: Australian active coronavirus cases dip below 500 for the first time since March as recoveries outpace new infections
weeklyTopNews.summary: The number of active cases of coronavirus in Australia has dipped below 500 as the number of Australians recovering from the disease continues to outstrip the number of new infections recorded each day. More than 6,500 people have recovered from the virus, while a further 102 people have died due to COVID-19 since the pandemic took hold. It leaves just 484 currently infected with COVID-19. While data on recovered cases was not consistently reported earlier than April 5, the total number of confirmed cases in Australia was last below 500 on March 17.

weeklyTopNews.title: Victoria eases coronavirus restrictions; what you can do from June 1
weeklyTopNews.summary: Victoria has announced it will further ease coronavirus restrictions from June 1, reopening parks and allowing up to 20 people to gather at once. Restaurants and cafes will be allowed to seat and serve more customers, but bars serving alcohol without food must remain closed and people are encouraged to continue working from home when possible. A breakdown of the new restrictions can be found in the article below.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW beauty salons can reopen from June 1 as coronavirus restrictions ease
weeklyTopNews.summary: Beauty salons will be allowed to reopen in New South Wales on June 1. This includes nail salons, tanning salons and waxing salons, as long as the business has a COVID-safe plan in place and there are no more than ten clients in a business at one time. Salons must still adhere to strict social distancing regulations including the four square metre rule, limiting the number of patrons they can treat at a time, and create a COVID-safe plan before their re-opening.

weeklyTopNews.title: Scott Morrison dismisses calls for Josh Frydenberg to front Covid-19 inquiry over jobkeeper
weeklyTopNews.summary: Labor will attempt to pressure the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, to appear before the Senate’s Covid-19 inquiry to explain the “$60bn black hole” in the jobkeeper program – but the government has dismissed the call as a political stunt. However, Prime Minister Scott Morrison denied the revision (which means just 3.5 million workers are likely to be covered by the $1,500 fortnightly payment, not the 6.5 million estimated at one point) raised any issue with the government’s overall economic competence.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW govt eyes opening gyms, beauty salons
weeklyTopNews.summary: The NSW government has flagged the "imminent" re-opening of gyms and beauty salons as the state over the next two weeks prepares for a landmark easing of COVID-19 restrictions. The government remains cautious yet bullish after three cases of coronavirus were recorded over the preceding 24 hours. All three were overseas acquired - two from Pakistan and one from the USA - and were already in hotel quarantine meaning they didn't represent a risk of onward infection. Premier Gladys Berejiklian has announced that from June 1, up to 50 people will be allowed in restaurants, pubs and cafes. Regional travel restrictions will also ease while museums, galleries and libraries will also be allowed to open.

weeklyTopNews.title: Government's $60b accounting bungle ups pressure to extend JobKeeper scheme as economy recovers from COVID-19
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Australian Government is facing tough questions about whether they plan to reallocate the $60 billion windfall following the ATO's JobKeeper bungle. The Government had budgeted for the JobKeeper scheme to cost $130 billion however the actual price tag has been reduced to $70 billion after major miscalculations by the Australian Taxation Office due to a confusing question on the application sheet. Australians were told six and a half million workers would receive these payments but that number has been revised down to three and a half million following the revision of figures. With $60 billion now on the table, various stakeholders are trying to get their hands on a portion of the money with calls to extend the JobKeeper scheme to those still in need.

weeklyTopNews.title: JobKeeper numbers cut by 3 million after Federal Government reveals accounting bungle in coronavirus stimulus program
weeklyTopNews.summary: The number of people on JobKeeper has been revised down by 3 million, with Treasury and the Australian Tax Office (ATO) blaming businesses for making "significant errors" in their applications. The estimated cost of the program has been nearly halved from $130 billion to about $70 billion. In a statement, Treasury and the ATO said the mistake came from businesses reporting how much financial assistance they expected to receive, instead of how many employees they thought would be eligible.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions relaxed for restaurants, pubs and cafes, Premier Gladys Berejiklian reveals
weeklyTopNews.summary: Premier Gladys Berejiklian says pubs, cafes and restaurants will be able to serve up to 50 people at a time from June 1, as NSW coronavirus cases continue to decline. The Premier described expanding the social-distancing limits as a "big step" in the state's economic recovery from COVID-19. Under the new measures, hospitality venues will be required to adhere to strict guidelines to operate: each patron must have at least four-square-metres of space; bookings can be no larger than 10 people; no patrons will be allowed to stand, mingle or dance; and shared cutlery and buffets are also banned.
